name: Agriculture
description: Historically one of the first domains to exploit Earth Observation (EO), agriculture is the most promising market in terms of the impact of Copernicus.
notes: Highest penetration rate of Copernicus; substantial impact on revenues of sector.

name: Forestry
description: Forest ownership varies by country between public and private entities. EO supports revenue generation for VAS providers.
notes: Few commercial applications exploit forestry EO products, making benefits to end users difficult to quantify.

name: Urban Monitoring
description: Offers a wide span of EO applications, benefiting smart city development.
notes: Market expected to grow with smart city applications; end users face budget constraints but show encouraging trends.

name: Ocean Monitoring
description: EO applications involve diverse stakeholders including private companies, public authorities, and research centres.
notes: Rapidly changing environment requires near-real-time EO data; Sentinel-3 expected to increase Copernicus benefits.

name: Air Quality Monitoring
description: EO data applications are recent; historically based on meteorological data, statistics, and measurements.
notes: Individuals demonstrate low willingness to pay for air quality information, so end users’ needs are mostly addressed by public authorities.

name: Renewable Energies
description: Sector exploits EO for biomass and solar energy applications.

name: Natural Disaster Insurance
description: Copernicus benefits to intermediate users are low due to gaps between insurer needs and available EO products.
notes: End users’ potential benefits are higher considering high financial stakes; EO data often handled in-house or ignored by some insurers.

name: Oil and Gas
description: EO is mostly exploited in upstream activities. Copernicus data contributes via GIS products.
notes: End users’ benefits expected to be much higher given the scale of the markets.
